raw_response:
{
  "q3_revenue": "180,169",
  "q3_operating_income": "17,422",
  "q3_diluted_eps": "1.95",
  "q4_revenue_guidance": "206.0 - 213.0",
  "q4_operating_income_guidance": "21.0 - 26.0",
  "summary": "Amazon reported solid top-line growth in Q3 2025, with total net sales of $180.2 billion, representing 13% year-over-year growth (12% excluding foreign exchange). Growth was broad-based across all segments, led by continued acceleration in AWS and steady momentum in North America and International retail. Operating income totaled $17.4 billion, flat year-over-year, reflecting the impact of significant one-time charges during the quarter .

Segment performance highlighted AWS as the primary earnings and growth driver. AWS revenue increased 20% year-over-year to $33.0 billion, supported by strong demand for AI-related workloads and core infrastructure services. AWS operating income rose to $11.4 billion from $10.4 billion in the prior year, underscoring sustained margin strength despite elevated infrastructure investment and severance-related costs. Management emphasized re-accelerating cloud growth, driven by high demand for generative AI services, custom silicon such as Trainium2, and large-scale AI compute deployments .

North America segment sales grew 11% year-over-year to $106.3 billion, reflecting healthy consumer demand and advertising growth. However, segment operating income declined to $4.8 billion from $5.7 billion last year, primarily due to a $2.5 billion legal settlement with the Federal Trade Commission and $1.8 billion in severance costs related to planned role eliminations. Excluding the FTC settlement, North America operating income would have been $7.3 billion, indicating underlying profitability improvements driven by higher unit volumes and advertising revenue .

International segment sales increased 14% year-over-year to $40.9 billion (10% excluding FX), while operating income decreased modestly to $1.2 billion from $1.3 billion, also impacted by severance costs and ongoing investment in logistics and fulfillment capabilities. Management noted continued focus on efficiency initiatives to improve long-term margins in international markets.

Net income for Q3 2025 rose sharply to $21.2 billion, or $1.95 per diluted share, compared with $15.3 billion, or $1.43 per share, in the prior year. Results benefited from $9.5 billion of pre-tax gains related to Amazon’s investment in Anthropic, recorded in non-operating income .

Looking ahead, Amazon provided Q4 2025 revenue guidance of $206.0–$213.0 billion, implying 10%–13% year-over-year growth, with a favorable foreign exchange tailwind of approximately 190 basis points. Operating income for Q4 is expected to range from $21.0 billion to $26.0 billion, compared with $21.2 billion in Q4 2024. Guidance assumes no additional material acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements .

Key risks highlighted include ongoing macroeconomic uncertainty, foreign exchange volatility, elevated capital expenditures—particularly for AI and data center capacity—and potential regulatory and legal actions. Overall, the quarter reinforced Amazon’s strategic positioning around AI-driven growth and AWS scale, while near-term margins were tempered by discrete charges and continued investment."
}

parsed_response.summary:
Amazon reported solid top-line growth in Q3 2025, with total net sales of $180.2 billion, representing 13% year-over-year growth (12% excluding foreign exchange). Growth was broad-based across all segments, led by continued acceleration in AWS and steady momentum in North America and International retail. Operating income totaled $17.4 billion, flat year-over-year, reflecting the impact of significant one-time charges during the quarter .

Segment performance highlighted AWS as the primary earnings and growth driver. AWS revenue increased 20% year-over-year to $33.0 billion, supported by strong demand for AI-related workloads and core infrastructure services. AWS operating income rose to $11.4 billion from $10.4 billion in the prior year, underscoring sustained margin strength despite elevated infrastructure investment and severance-related costs. Management emphasized re-accelerating cloud growth, driven by high demand for generative AI services, custom silicon such as Trainium2, and large-scale AI compute deployments .

North America segment sales grew 11% year-over-year to $106.3 billion, reflecting healthy consumer demand and advertising growth. However, segment operating income declined to $4.8 billion from $5.7 billion last year, primarily due to a $2.5 billion legal settlement with the Federal Trade Commission and $1.8 billion in severance costs related to planned role eliminations. Excluding the FTC settlement, North America operating income would have been $7.3 billion, indicating underlying profitability improvements driven by higher unit volumes and advertising revenue .

International segment sales increased 14% year-over-year to $40.9 billion (10% excluding FX), while operating income decreased modestly to $1.2 billion from $1.3 billion, also impacted by severance costs and ongoing investment in logistics and fulfillment capabilities. Management noted continued focus on efficiency initiatives to improve long-term margins in international markets.

Net income for Q3 2025 rose sharply to $21.2 billion, or $1.95 per diluted share, compared with $15.3 billion, or $1.43 per share, in the prior year. Results benefited from $9.5 billion of pre-tax gains related to Amazon’s investment in Anthropic, recorded in non-operating income .

Looking ahead, Amazon provided Q4 2025 revenue guidance of $206.0–$213.0 billion, implying 10%–13% year-over-year growth, with a favorable foreign exchange tailwind of approximately 190 basis points. Operating income for Q4 is expected to range from $21.0 billion to $26.0 billion, compared with $21.2 billion in Q4 2024. Guidance assumes no additional material acquisitions, restructurings, or legal settlements .

Key risks highlighted include ongoing macroeconomic uncertainty, foreign exchange volatility, elevated capital expenditures—particularly for AI and data center capacity—and potential regulatory and legal actions. Overall, the quarter reinforced Amazon’s strategic positioning around AI-driven growth and AWS scale, while near-term margins were tempered by discrete charges and continued investment.
